awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Emerging Scholars Program at St. Mary's College of Maryland that builds on the 30-plus-year success record of Research Experience for Undergraduates: Emerging Scholars programs, helping underrepresented students prepare for the mathematics major, for graduate school, and for careers in a Science Technology Engineering and/or Mathematics related field.  In seven-week sessions during summers of 2016, 2018 and 2020, twelve students will work with professors at St. Mary's College of Maryland to research a variety of mathematical questions, including problems of interest to epidemiologists, optical engineers, and data analysts.  By recruiting students from underrepresented groups who are only one or two years into their college careers, this program provides a formative research experience for its participants.  

Participants of this ESP-REU program will engage in research projects in areas of Discrete Models in Epidemiology, Applied Optics, Discrete Geometry, Game Theory, Image Analysis, and Knot Theory that have been carefully chosen by faculty mentors.  Students will participate in regular seminars designed to prepare them for upper-level mathematics courses.  In addition, students will attend academic support sessions on scientific writing and communication, making effective mathematics presentations, applying to future REUs, selecting and applying to graduate programs, and finding and applying to STEM-related jobs.

por.por_cntn:
This program funded twelve students each summer. We specifically looked for underrepresented students at the beginning of their mathematics careers—two semesters of Calculus was the prerequisite, and students who had already taken any upper-level math classes were ineligible. A semester of Linear Algebra or Vector Calculus was fine, but Algebra, Analysis or any course at that level disqualified the applicant. We were not looking for the most accomplished students—they already know the joy of mathematics. Instead, we wanted to find students who might have otherwise slipped through the cracks—students who had real talent recognized by their professors, and real enthusiasm evidenced by their application, but who perhaps did not (yet) see themselves as real mathematicians.

In short, the goal was to find underrepresented students who may not have been aware of their own potential, and to recruit them to mathematics by introducing them to research early in their college careers.

During the REU, students worked with a mentor in one of three research groups. Their projects were designed carefully so that they could do original mathematics research, despite their modest preparation. Topics included Knot Theory, Graph Theory, Mathematical Modeling, Cellular Automata, Combinatorial Game Theory and Statistics. Remember—these were almost all rising sophomores with two semesters of calculus as the only prerequisites.

Outside their research groups, participants were given instruction in constructing and delivering presentations, writing mathematical papers, and speaking about their work informally to both mathematicians and non-mathematicians. They learned LaTeX, proof writing, induction, problem-solving strategies, and computing on platforms chosen from R, Matlab, Maple and Sage.

In addition, they got crash courses in the basics of Abstract Algebra and Analysis so that they were ahead of the game when they returned to their home institutions to begin more advanced coursework.

The program was a huge success. Nearly all of our participants went on to become math, statistics or computer science majors. Almost half attended a more traditional REU following their sophomore or junior year. Students who have since graduated have overwhelmingly remained within STEM disciplines for work or graduate school.

Several of the students received awards for outstanding posters or presentations at undergraduate math conferences. And, though not a priority for the program, four papers arising from the students' work were published in professional journals (i.e., not journals specializing in undergraduate mathematics).

There is more work to be done. I am grateful for the investments of time and resources that have allowed us to discover and support these students. And I look forward to ongoing efforts that encourage students from historically underrepresented and marginalized populations to become part of the mathematics community.
